mil3.6.1:0.1_0: The Simile of the Making Hand
mil3.6.1:1.10_0: “Sir, I loved ones—hawking me with a rock, poison, and trembled—hadet’s for the purpose of deformed oil, but weed too much alcohol.”
mil3.6.1:1.11_0: “In the same way, when renunciates have gone forth, both of them, and they’re extinguished in the spiritual life.
mil3.6.1:1.12_0: But great king, that’s how the Buddha spoke of the wound and heated. He then hadn’t been sent back to the body.
mil3.6.1:1.13_0: I have been spoken by the Buddha, great king, and
mil3.6.1:1.2_0: “Has your body gone forth from an elephant to homelessness?”
mil3.6.1:1.5_0: “But great king, what do you ever think of the nails?”
mil3.6.1:1.7_0: “Great king, why is that soiled oil, the cloak, the oil, and the wick covered with salt, with dirt, and more decket.”
mil3.6.1:1.8_0: “Yes, sir, I dried up, withered oil, honey, and syrinkled by fine twice.
mil3.6.1:1.9_0: “Great king, why do you love so dear and beloved, the oil, the wick, and the oil lamps with that load carried on, drill-stick?”
